chapter.title: Configuring destinations
chapter.para: The &agent; application can send the log messages of the Windows host to a central log server or relay. It is possible to send the same messages to multiple servers, when each server receives the same messages; and also to configure failover servers, when the agent sends the messages to a primary server, or to a failover server if the primary becomes unavailable. If the agent loses the connection to a destination server and the reconnection fails, it will generate an eventlog message. The successful reconnection attempt is also logged. (If the server is unavailable for a long time, the agent generates a log message about the failed connection once in every ten seconds.)

If the failover server also becomes unavailable, the application will switch to the next failover server, and so on. If the last failover server is unavailable, it switches back to the primary. The application does not switch back automatically to the primary server if it becomes available again, only if the syslog-ng Agent for Windows has been restarted.

note.para: The failover servers will use the same options that the primary server uses. Only the name and the address can be configured for the failover servers.

chapter.para: Similarly to the Linux version, the agent now sends MARK messages to the server to indicate that the client host is alive but there are no log messages to send. A MARK message is sent every ten minutes.

warning.para: The &agent; application does not support the unreliable UDP protocol. Configure your central log server to accept logs using TCP or TLS connections. If needed, adjust your firewall configuration to permit such traffic to the log server.

procedure.title: Configuring the destination log servers
procedure.para: To configure a new destination, complete the following steps:

step.para: Start the configuration interface of the &agent; application.
Select syslog-ng Agent Settings > Destinations, and double-click on Add new server.

Enter the hostname or the IP address of the log server into the Server Name or Address (IPv4) field. If your log server is configured to accept messages on a non-standard port, type the port number into the Server Port field. To use the default port (35514 when RLTP is enabled and 514 when RLTP is disabled), click Reset to Default Port.
To enable flow-control, select Enable flow-control. For details, see .
To use SSL encryption, enable Use SSL encryption. For details, see .
Optional Step: To use the Reliable Log Transfer Protocol (RLTP), enable Use syslog-ng proprietary Reliable Log Transfer Protocol (RLTP). For details on the concepts of RLTP, see .
Click Advanced Options.
Change the following options if necessary:

note.para: Do not adjust or modify the following settings unless you know exactly what you are doing.

listitem.para: Transaction Size: The number of messages sent before waiting for acknowledgement from the server.
Response Timeout: After not receiving any message in the given timeframe, &agentabbrev; terminates the connection with the server.
Acknowledge Timeout: After not receiving any reply to the messages in the given timeframe, &agentabbrev; terminates the connection with the server.

step.para: Click OK.

On Messages tab, select the protocol used to transfer log messages and press Reset to apply the selected template. The following protocol templates are available (for details on the default templates and on customizing the message format, see ):

listitem.para: Legacy BSD Syslog Protocol: Use the legacy BSD-syslog protocol specified in RFC3164. This option uses the following message template: <${PRI}>${BSDDATE} ${HOST} ${MSGHDR}${MESSAGE}. Within the message part, &agentabbrev; replaces CRLF with 2 spaces and TAB character with 1 space.

example.title: Legacy BSD Syslog Protocol log
example.synopsis: <134>Oct 04 14:45:33 zts-win019.ztswin2008dom.balabit Microsoft-Windows-Eventlog[2880]: ZTSWIN2008DOM\balabit: System Microsoft-Windows-Eventlog: [Information] The Application log file was cleared. (EventID 104)

listitem.para: Syslog Protocol: Use the new IETF-syslog protocol specified in RFC 5424-5426. This is the default setting.

When using the IETF-syslog protocol to transfer Eventlog messages, the &agentabbrev; application includes the macros (name-value pairs) in the SDATA part of the log message by default. This includes every available Event macro, except EVENT_MSG (EVENT_MESSAGE), EVENT_MSG_XML (EVENT_MESSAGE_XML). Macros that do not have a value will not be included in the message.
listitem.synopsis: 499 <132>1 2010-09-28T12:02:30+02:00 zts-win004.ztswin2003dom.balabit testapp 1220 - [win@18372.4 EVENT_ID="1000" EVENT_NAME="Application" EVENT_REC_NUM="1673" EVENT_SID="S-1-5-21-3460971693-970282485-2299281428-1001" EVENT_SID_TYPE="User" EVENT_SOURCE="testapp" EVENT_TYPE="Warning" EVENT_USERNAME="ZTS-WIN004\\balabit"][meta sequenceId="1" sysUpTime="1"] ﻿ZTS-WIN004\balabit: Application testapp: [Warning] test message (EventID 1000)

note.para: The names of SDATA fields must be in the following format: name@<private enterprise number>, for example, mySDATA-field@18372.4. (18372.4 is the private enterprise number of BalaBit IT Security, the developer of &agent;.)

listitem.para: Messages received from eventlog sources include the win@18372.4 SD-ID. For example, on your &abbrev; server you can refer to message fields like: ${.SDATA.win@18372.4.EVENT_SOURCE}
Messages received from eventlog sources include the file@18372.4 SD-ID. For example, on your &abbrev; server you can refer to message fields like: ${.SDATA.file@18372.4.name}

To include only the data mandated by RFC5424, disable Include Eventlog message metadata as SDATA. To do this, navigate to Destinations > Destination Global Settings, select Enable and deselect Include Eventlog message metadata as SDATA. For example, only the following data will be included in the message:
Snare Protocol: Send log messages in a format compatible with the Snare log monitoring tool.

note.para: Snare is a tab-separated message format. Within the message part, agent replaces CRLF with 2 space, TAB character with 1 space.
You cannot modify the log format if you have selected this protocol.

example.title: Snare log
example.synopsis: <134>Oct 06 13:49:41 zts-win019.ztswin2008dom.balabit MSWinEventLog 1 Application 1 Wed Oct 06 13:49:41 2010 1 syslog-ng Agent S-1-5-21-551780264-1021859348-3425375765-1003 User Information zts-win019.ztswin2008dom.balabit None Application started 1

note.para: Selecting the Syslog Protocol option is identical to using the syslog driver in the Linux/Unix version of syslog-ng. Similarly, selecting Legacy BSD Syslog Protocol is equivalent to the tcp driver of syslog-ng.
Changing to the Legacy BSD Protocol does not automatically restore the original template. To do so, click Reset Protocol Template after modifying the protocol.

step.para: If needed, modify the template of the messages. The format of the messages can be different for the eventlog and the file sources.

warning.para: The maximal length of the template is 1023 characters.

step.para: If you have a backup server that can accept log messages if the primary log server becomes unavailable, select the Failover Servers tab, click Add, and enter the hostname or the IP address of the backup log server into the Server Name field. Repeat this step if you have more than one backup servers.

If you want to send the log messages to more than on server in parallel, so that every server receives every message, repeat Steps 3-4 to add the other destination servers. These servers may have failover servers as well.
Select Apply, then OK. To activate the changes, restart the &agentabbrev; service.

Optional Step: If the host running &agentabbrev; is sometimes logged in into a domain, sometimes not, then its hostname might change depending on its actual domain membership. This can cause that the hostname appearing in the syslog messages depends on the domain membership of the host. To avoid this situation, select syslog-ng Agent Settings > Global Settings > Hostname > Use FQDN. That way &agentabbrev; resolves the name of its host from the DNS server, and uses the resolved FQDN in the syslog messages.

procedure.title: Limiting the rate of messages
procedure.para: The &agentabbrev; can control the rate of messages (message per second) sent to the central server. That way sudden message-bursts can be avoided, and the load of the server is decreased.
To limit the number of messages sent to a destination, complete the following steps:

step.para: Start the configuration interface of the &agent; application.
Select syslog-ng Agent Settings > Destinations.

Select Destination Global Settings. To limit the number of messages that the &agentabbrev; sends to the server per second, enter the desired limit into the Throttle field. By default (0), the &agentabbrev; does not limit the number of messages sent.
The throttling parameter applies to the total number of messages sent, not to every source independently. The same value applies to every destination.
Click OK. To activate the changes, restart the &agentabbrev; service.

procedure.title: Sending MARK messages
procedure.para: If there are no new messages that have to be sent to the destination server, the &agent; application automatically sends a MARK message every ten minutes to notify the server that the connection is still active. The exact format of the MARK message depends on the protocol:
To change how often the &agentabbrev; sends these messages, complete the following steps.

step.para: Start the configuration interface of the &agent; application.
Select syslog-ng Agent Settings and double-click on Global Settings.
Select Enable, then select Mark Mode Options.
Set the frequency of MARK messages that the &agent; application sends.

listitem.para: Never: Do not send MARK messages.
When destination idle: Send MARK messages only if there were no other messages sent to the destination during the specified period.
Periodically: Send MARK messages every time the specified period expires.

step.para: Set the time between two MARK messages in the The number of seconds between two MARK messages. By default, this is 600 seconds (10 minutes).
Select Apply, then OK. To activate the changes, restart the &agentabbrev; service.

section.title: Flow-control in &agent;
section.para: Starting with version 5 LTS, the flow-control feature of &product; is automatically enabled for the destinations. Using flow-control means that the &agentabbrev; will stop reading messages from the sources if the destination cannot accept them (for example, because of a network error). For details on the concepts of flow-control, see .
To enable or disable flow-control for a destination, select syslog-ng Agent Settings > Destinations, double-click on the destination, then select Server > Enable flow-control.

note.para: The flow-control of &agentabbrev; 5 LTS replaces the Primary Server option of earlier versions.
